Black History Month should be part of every month

07/10/2021

Incorporating black history into our curriculum is an essential way to combat discrimination

Image by Steve Eason

By Molli Tyldesley

We're now a few days into October, which is also known for being Black History Month.Â However, black history is tooÂ rich to be taught for only one month,Â and the curriculum must give it theÂ same treatment as the rest of history.Â We cannot repeat the same few basicÂ facts every October and call it enoughÂ black history for the year.

History is written by the victors,Â meaning we are unequally educatedÂ about Britainâ€™s past. Schools teachÂ us about our triumphs yet gloss overÂ our atrocities. Personifying this isÂ ex-Education Secretary Gavin Williamson, who rejected teaching moreÂ about colonialism, instead emphasising celebrating our contributions toÂ the world.Â Before the Second World War,Â Britain could get away with views likeÂ Williamsonâ€™s, but since then BritainÂ has become a multicultural society.

"If we are better educated on racism and its continuing impact, people will be more empathetic and understanding to the importance of being anti-racist, not just non-racist, in kicking racism out of our society."

Black history must be acknowledgedÂ so that black children understand thatÂ they have a history to be proud of justÂ like their white classmates. PresentingÂ British history in its totality means weÂ can understand Europeâ€™s role in whyÂ black history is not better understood.Â History lessons can and should beÂ used to right the wrongs of our past.Â After the recent appointment of refugee Nadhim Zahawi as Williamsonâ€™sÂ replacement, it will be interesting toÂ see whether his same views are echoed, or if Zahawi brings a new perspective on the importance of diversifying the curriculum.

European powers committed aÂ cultural genocide in Africa, erasingÂ its traditions, values and architecture.Â This creates the narrative that blackÂ people have no history or achievements to celebrate. Therefore, it is vital we are taught black people have aÂ rich history which restores a sense ofÂ pride in their heritage, inspiring themÂ to embrace their culture.Â When asked what the largestÂ structure ever made was, many peopleÂ say the Great Wall of China. However,Â not many people know that the WallsÂ of Benin, in Nigeria, were 10,000Â miles long, four times the length ofÂ the Great Wall of China. Most likelyÂ because the British destroyed it inÂ 1897. Also, not many people willÂ know that Africans may have crossedÂ the Atlantic centuries before the Europeans, with the Olmec ColossalÂ Heads in Mexico undeniably possessing black peoples facial features.

African history isnâ€™t just foundÂ outside of Britain however. DespiteÂ the â€˜Windrush Mythâ€™ that black Brit-ish history starts with the immigration from the Caribbean after WorldÂ War Two, black British history canÂ be traced back to the Romans, withÂ the African born Emperor SeptimiusÂ Severus helping to build Hadrianâ€™sÂ Wall and dying in York.Â Another significant era of blackÂ British history often untaught is theÂ black abolitionists of the 18th Century. While most of us have heard aboutÂ the prominent abolitionist WilliamÂ Wilberforce, not many will have heardÂ of Olaudah Equiano, who brought hisÂ freedom from slavery before settlingÂ in Britain and played a significant roleÂ in abolishing slavery, largely throughÂ his literature highlighting its horrors.

Teaching black history also combats prejudice and discrimination.Â Even here in York, black students areÂ still affected by ignorant and racist remarks. The lack of diversity is hard toÂ miss for any student from non-whiteÂ backgrounds, and this unknowinglyÂ creates a safe climate for racists, whoÂ feel free to use racist language.Â I myself am from a mixed British and Caribbean background and IÂ am sure I am not the only person fromÂ multi-ethnic or black backgroundsÂ who is familiar with the questionÂ â€œwhere are you from?â€. People are notÂ always satisfied when I respond withÂ â€œLondonâ€, as if black people cannotÂ originate from there. White peopleÂ have openly said the N-word aroundÂ me, and even tell me that I should notÂ be offended by it.

YUSU BAME Network askedÂ black students for any incidents of racism they have faced in York. One student was called a â€œlittle monkeyâ€ byÂ their flatmate, while others have beenÂ patronised by people complimentingÂ their ability to speak English. A student nurse had a patient refuse theirÂ care, was asked if they had ever wornÂ socks in Africa before coming to YorkÂ and if they knew a witchdoctor. Another student was singled out by theirÂ landlord for lacking the â€œYorkshireÂ personalityâ€ despite other housemates also not being from Yorkshire.Â When telling the estate agents aboutÂ the incident, the estate agents refusedÂ to accept it was over their skin colour,Â adding further salt to the wound.

Ignorant comments like theseÂ can be tackled by creating a curriculum that embraces black history asÂ teaching the full history of black people destroys narrative that they wereÂ less educated and uncivilised. If we areÂ better educated on racism and its continuing impact, people will becomeÂ more empathetic and understandingÂ to the importance of being anti-racist,Â not just non-racist, in kicking racismÂ out of our society.

So, why has there not been anyÂ major shifts in our curriculum sinceÂ Black History Month was first celebrated here 34 years ago? If peopleÂ understand the lasting impact of ourÂ past on modern-day countries, theyÂ will demand change. Seemingly, itÂ is not in the government's interestÂ to educate people on black history.Â People will hold the government accountable for ensuring they live up toÂ their responsibility to the people whoÂ for centuries were told that they wereÂ British. However, as the handling ofÂ the Windrush Scandal shows, theÂ government does not want to acceptÂ that responsibility. The government isÂ fearful of the result that teaching moreÂ black history will have, as it will meanÂ people will demand more meaningfulÂ actions from them which jeopardisesÂ the status quo.

Currently history classes tell usÂ how much of a global superpower weÂ were. Since we lost that status decades ago, it is time that schools catchÂ up. The sooner the government relinquishes control of how we view ourÂ history, the sooner we can make thisÂ country better for everyone and make a Britain which is truly Great.
